docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
I've always looked for a general strategy to solve geometry problems beside converting it into pure algebra. Recently, I've had some breakthroughs in developing such a strategy, particularly in rotation & linear transformation.

This section includes some of my results. I'll keep expanding this section to include more.

Basic Division:

  • Linear Transformation (LinTrans)
  • Basic Structures and Ideas (including some nonlinearties) (BS)
  • Rotations (rot)
  • Half-angle Constructions (\(\frac{\alpha}{2}\))
  • Line Construction
    • Parallel Lines
    • Intersecting Lines
  • Circles
    • Basics (circ)
    • Centers of a Triangle

docs.title: Basic Structures and Ideas
docs.text: This is basically a cheatsheet of all the useful structures.

docs.title: List of Structures
docs.text:
1. Fixed Length ⇒ Circle
  2. Fixed Angle + Fixed Length ⇒ Circle
  3. Fixed Ratio to Fixed Endpoints ⇒ Circle
  4. All the Linear Transformation Techniques
  5. Inversion (Reflection About Circle)
  6. Fixed Angle + Fixed Intersection (with another line) ⇒ Line
  7. 2 Fixed Points ⇒ Line

docs.title: List of Ideas
docs.text:
1. Any construction you made must connect ast least 2 conditions. Otherwise, it would be a dangling construction, and the amount of information you can get out of this auxiliary constructing is the same as the amount you constructed, so you will get no new information.
  2. After constructing auxiliary lines, try to reframe the original problem in the new (simpler) figure.
  3. Try to find relationships between all angles and segments to see if there is some special relationship if there is no clear path forward.
  4. Try to use transformation to ensure the parts you are trying to relate are in the same orientation, scale, and chirality.
  5. When trying to find a locus of a point, try finding a fixpoint related to the point, then find the locus via the relationship.
  6. Try simpler versions of the problem (special cases) to get of feeling of the problem.

docs.title: General Idea
docs.text: In most cases, two angles with a ratio of 2 can be constructed to give either an angle bisector or an isosceles triangle (or both.) An isosceles triangle would be preferable, as it already gives a very simple side relationship (\(AB = AC\))

docs.title: Symmetry Construct
docs.text: This the simplest form of half angle.The figure is symmetric about the angle bisector, so make full use of its symmetry.

docs.title: Properties:
docs.text:
1. \(AO = BO\)
  2. \(AH = BH\)
  3. \(HC = HD\)
  4. \(AB \perp OH\)
  5. \(HC \perp OA\)
  6. \(HD \perp OB\)
  7. \(OH \,\text{bisects}\, \angle AOB\)

docs.title: Parallel Construct
docs.text: Let \(OC \,\text{bisects}\, \angle AOB\).

docs.title: Method 1
docs.text: Construct \(BD \parallel OC\) intersects \(AO\) at \(D\). (Construct line parallel to bisector.) ⇒ \(OD = OB\)

docs.title: Method 2
docs.text: Construct \(BD \parallel OA\) intersects \(OC\) at \(D\). (Construct line parallel to side.) ⇒ \(BO = BD\)

docs.title: Angle Bisector Theorem
docs.text:
Construction:

  1. \(OI \,\text{bisects}\, \angle AOB\) intersects \(AB\) at \(I\)
  2. \(OJ \,\text{bisects}\, \angle BOC\) intersects \(AB\) at \(J\)

Properties:

  1. \(\frac{AO}{OB} = \frac{AI}{BI} = \frac{AJ}{BJ}\)
  2. \(\angle IOJ = 90^\circ\)

which is basically Apollonius Theorem.

docs.title: Co-vertex
docs.text: This is when \(\angle COD = \frac{1}{2} \angle AOB\), where \(\triangle AOB\) is an isosceles triangle.

docs.title: Basic Idea
docs.text: Just rotate \(\angle AOC\) (and the triangle it's in) about \(O\) to \(\angle BOD\), then \(OD \,\text{bisects}\, \angle COD\). Make use of the symmetry in the angle bisector.

docs.title: Recognition
docs.text:
This is the hardest part of the Co-vertex type.

Properties:

  1. The circumcenter \(I\) of \(\triangle BOC\) is on OC.
  2. If \(\angle AOB = 90^\circ\), \(OEFBC\) are all on \(\odot I\)

docs.title: Examples
docs.text: 1. 《核心考点·九上》P82 04

docs.title: Translation
docs.text: \[ + \begin{bmatrix} \Delta x \\ \Delta y \end{bmatrix} \]

docs.title: Rotation
docs.text:
\[ \begin{bmatrix} \cos(\theta) & -\sin(\theta) \\ \sin(\theta) & \cos(\theta) \end{bmatrix} \]

for counter-clockwise rot

docs.title: Dilation
docs.text:
\[ k \mathbf{p} + (1 - k) \mathbf{c} \]

This is basically a weighted sum, where \(\mathbf{p}\) is the original point, and \(\mathbf{c}\) is the center of the transformation.

docs.title: Special Case (reflection about point):
docs.text: \[ 2 \mathbf{c} - \mathbf{p} \]

docs.title: Reflection (about line through origin)
docs.text:
\[ \begin{bmatrix} \cos(2 \theta) & \sin(2 \theta) \\ -\sin(2 \theta) & \cos(2 \theta) \end{bmatrix} \]

where \(\theta\) is the angle between x-axis and reflection axis. See Trigonometry for calculation of \(\cos(2\theta) \, \sin(2\theta)\) with \(\cos(\theta) \, \sin(\theta)\). For reflection about any line, first do a translation then apply this matrix then translate back.

docs.title: Note
docs.text: Any translation + dilation + rotation (can be about different centers) can be rewritten as a single rotation + scale (about a single point.)

docs.title: Single Point in Motion + Translation
docs.text:
Let \(\mathbf{u} = A \mathbf{x} + \mathbf{b}\) if \(\mathbf{v}\) is related to \(\mathbf{u}\) via a linear transformation

\[ \begin{align*} \mathbf{v} & = M \mathbf{u} + \mathbf{d} \\ & = M (A \mathbf{x} + \mathbf{b}) + \mathbf{d} \\ & = \underbrace{M A \mathbf{x}}_{\text{transform orignal motion}} + \underbrace{(M \mathbf{b} + d)}_{\text{transform orignal motion's center}} \end{align*} \]

docs.title: Example
docs.text: Transformation in Linalg ⇒ Similar Triangles ($ \triangle BDU \sim \triangle B'DV $, but here's a special case where it is congruent)

docs.title: Two Points in Motion
docs.text: Denote points \(A \, B\). Idea: Transform \(AB\) to make either \(A'\) or \(B'\) stationary. (Often uses translation)

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
Given equilateral \(\triangle ABC\), \(CD = BE\). Find \(\min(DE)\). Translates \(ED\) to \(E'D'\) ⇒ \(CD = DD' ,\, \angle CDD' = 120^\circ\) ⇒ \(\angle DCD' = 30^\circ\) (locus of \(D'\))

For more points, the idea is the same: use some transformations to make points stationary.

docs.title: Further Examples
docs.text: • R5 (solvable with Idea 2 but redundant if the original point's path is an arc)

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
Most circles are hidden inside the figures, they are a crucial yet often overlooked part of geometry problem-solving.

The reason behind its wide usage is how simple it is to construct it, and how there are so many ways to construct it. Any fixed length, fixed angle, equal angles (except when the sides are parallel), fixed ratio will produce a circle. Even in scenarios such as the Co-vertex Half Angle, there are circles hidden, just because the angle's relationship happens to be right. It also has many properties, serving as a bridge to connects angles (with equal arcs, etc.) and lengths (equal radii, Ptolemy, etc.)

Circles can be constructed with rotated angles, therefore nearly any rotation will generate circles. It can also be used to construct rotations backwards.

Circles have connection to a triangle's various centers. Many of those centers' properties need circle + similar triangles for derivation. These are the hardest kinds of problems in circle geometry.

docs.title: Fixed Length
docs.text: This is literally the definition. Occurs in some problems involving folding.

docs.title: Case 1: With a Fixed Length
docs.text:
In this case, the vertex traces a fixed circle. There's an even more special case, where the angle is \(90^\circ\), then the center of the circle is the midpoint of the fixed segment。

And every chord / arc have a corresponding angle. In some cases, the corresponding angle is given, and it can be used to derive other angles directly. When the radius of the circle and the chord length are given, we'll have to calculate its corresponding angle. The most common case is with the diameter.

docs.title: Examples:
docs.text:
1. Incenter path
  2. Foot of some perpendicular construction (as shown below)

docs.title: Case 2: Without Fixed Length
docs.text:
Let \(\angle ABC = \theta\). In this case, constructing the circum circle might still be useful, as it creates a relationship between \(AB\) and \(r_{\odot}\), namely:

\[ AB = 2 \sin(\theta) r_{\odot} \]

docs.title: Examples:
docs.text:
1. Spotlight (shown below)
  2. R5

docs.title: Fixed Ratio + Fixed Length
docs.text:
This is Apollonius Circle Theorem (also mentioned in Half Angle Construction.) Obviously you can use the Angle Bisector Theorem to derive this, but there's a better way:

Let segment be \(AB\), and \(\frac{CA}{CB} = k\). The \(C\) traces \(\odot O\).

\[ \begin{align*} & \triangle OCA \sim \triangle OBC \\ \Rightarrow & \frac{OA}{OC}=\frac{OC}{OB}=\frac{AC}{BC}=k \\ \Rightarrow & r = \frac{k}{1 - k^2} AB \,\, \text{(assuming k < 1)} \end{align*} \]

docs.title: Minimize Distance
docs.text: This is the standard application, where the circle is given and \(BC\) is given, and you need to construct \(AC=kBC\). Same method as above.

docs.title: Minimize Ratio
docs.text:
Consider what happens when \(k\) is decreased from \(1\): the radius of the circle also decreases. So there must be a point where \(C\) cannot satisfy being on the circle (so ratio is correct) and the other constraints of the problem. This is the minimum.

However, this is not the standard way to solve the problem. Most of the time, we can construct a rotation (or some other similar triangle) to transform the ratio into a distance. Then we can use methods like inversion or something to find the path of one end.

There is also another way to use this, by seeing the circle AS the Apollonius Circle, and constructing the second end point. See R(n) for details.

docs.title: Equal Angles
docs.text: Any two equal angles (except when their legs are parallel) will produce four points that are concyclic.

docs.title: Construction
docs.text:
Extend the legs of the two angles so they intersect. The extension may be backwards.

When the vertex of one angle is on another's leg, then that leg is tangent to the circle.

docs.title: Application
docs.text: This is usually used to relate two equal angles.

docs.title: Note
docs.text: All the angle relationships in the circle can be obtained without the circle but with similar triangles.

docs.title: Centers of a Triangle
docs.text: Let the trangle be \(\triangle ABC\) and its circumcenter be \(O\).

docs.title: Incenter
docs.text: Let the triangle's incenter be \(I\).

docs.title: Idea
docs.text:
1. Half Angle Construction

  2. If \(I\) happens to be a midpoint (\(D\)) of two points each on \(AB ,\, AC\) (\(E,\,F\)), then:

  3. This is the special case below

  4. \(\triangle BED \sim \triangle DFC\) (midpoint L3A)

  5. Construct the tangent points

docs.title: Path
docs.text: When \(\angle A\) is fixed (i.e. A is on a circle), then \(\angle BIC = 90^\circ + \frac{1}{2} \angle A\) is also a fixed angle. Thus, \(I\) is also on a circle whose center is the midpoint (\(M\)) of \(\overset{\Large\frown}{BC}\).

docs.title: Condition
docs.text: \[ \angle AIO = 90^\circ \]

docs.title: Properties
docs.text:
1. \(OI\) is tangent to \(\odot M\).
  2. Extend \(AI\) to intersect BC at \(D\), then \(DI = MI = \frac{1}{2} AI = \frac{1}{4} AM\).
  3. \(AB + AC = 2 BC\)
  4. Idea 2

docs.title: Orthocenter
docs.text: Let the orthocenter be \(H\), and the foot of the three heights be \(I\) (which is on \(AB\)), \(J\) (on \(BC\)), and \(K\) (on \(AC\)).

docs.title: Properties of \(\triangle IJK\)
docs.text:
1. Of all the triangles with points on each of \(AB,\,BC,\,AC\), \(\triangle IJK\) has the least circumference.
  2. \(H\) is the incenter of \(\triangle IJK\).

  3. Concyclic Groups:

    • \(ABJK\)
    • \(BCIK\)
    • \(ACIJ\)
    • \(AIKH\)
    • \(BIJH\)
    • \(CJKH\)

docs.title: Idea
docs.text:
Extend \(AO ,\, AH\) to intersect \(\odot O\) at \(D ,\, E\), \(DH\) intersects \(BC\) at \(F\) then:

  1. Produces parallelogram \(BDCH\)
  2. \(F\) in the midpoint of BC
  3. \(BC \parallel DE\)

docs.title: Properties
docs.text:
1. Let the distance from \(O\) to \(BC\) be \(a\), then \(AH = 2a\)
  2. \(2r = d = \frac{AB \cdot AC}{AD}\) Derivation: Extend \(BO\) to intersect \(\odot O\) at \(P\), then \(\triangle ABP \sim \triangle DAC\)
  3. If \(\angle BAC = 60^\circ\), then \(AO = AH\).

docs.title: Other Centers
docs.text: These centers are not strictly related to the circle.

docs.title: Centroid
docs.text: Let the centroid be \(G\).

docs.title: Property
docs.text: Extend \(AG\) to intersect \(BC\) at \(D\), then \(AG = 2DG\).

docs.title: Fermat's Point
docs.text: Let the Fermat's point be \(P\).

docs.title: Properties
docs.text:
1. Of all points in the plane, \(P\) minimizes \(AP + BP + CP\). (Derived through rotation)
  2. \(\angle APB = \angle BPC = \angle APC = 120^\circ\)
  3. Construction of \(P\): Construct equilateral triangles with \(AB ,\, BC ,\, AC\) as sides, then connect the other vertex of the equilateral triangle with the opposite vertex of \(\triangle ABC\). Their intersection is \(P\).

docs.title: Construct
docs.text: Quadrilateral \(ABCD\) is inscribed in \(\odot O\). \(AC\) and \(BD\) intersects at \(E\). Extend \(AB ,\, DC\) to intersect at \(F\).

docs.title: Basic Similarities
docs.text: Think about these relationships whenever concyclic points appear, particularly in the case where you don't actually need the angles in the circle, just side relationships. The same goes for Ptolemy.

docs.title: Inside Quadrilateral
docs.text:
\[ \triangle ABE \sim \triangle DCE \] \[ \triangle BCE \sim \triangle ADE \]

These pairs give relationships for segments INSIDE the quadrilateral.

docs.title: Outside Quadrilateral
docs.text:
\[ \triangle FBC \sim \triangle FDA \] \[ \triangle FAD \sim \triangle FCB \]

These pairs give relationships for segments OUTSIDE the quadrilateral.

docs.title: Ptolemy's Theorem
docs.text: \[ \left| AB \cdot CD - AD \cdot BC \right| \leq AC \cdot BD \leq AB \cdot CD + AD \cdot BC \]

docs.title: Equality Case
docs.text:
When the left side is equal, \((A,\,C,\,B,\,D)\) (or \((A,\,B,\,D,\,C)\), in order) is concyclic.

When the right side is equal, \((A,\,B,\,C,\,D)\) is concyclic.

docs.title: Derivation
docs.text: Construct rotation on \(\angle BAC = \angle BDC\). Specifically choose point \(G\) on \(AC\) s.t. \(\angle ABG = \angle DBC\). Then use the double similarity to solve.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
Used to find inequality relationships in a quadrilateral. Best used when the other axis of freedom are homogeneous when written down.

This is also the IN-OUT relationship part.

docs.title: Condition
docs.text: \[ AB = CB \]

docs.title: Properties
docs.text:
1. The similarity in the Ptolemy case reduces to congruency, giving: $AD + BD = 2 AB \sin ABC $
  2. Inv-A Similarity: \(\triangle BAE \sim \triangle BDA\)
  3. Collinear Rotation: \(\triangle BDA \sim \triangle CDE\)

docs.title: Problem
docs.text: Given point \(P\) moving on \(\odot O\), and two fixed endpoints \(A\) and \(B\). Find \(\min(\frac{AP}{BP})\) (or max.)

docs.title: Idea 1
docs.text: We find that the ratio is very hard to cope with. Therefore, we try to transform it to the minimum length of a single segment via similar triangles.

docs.title: Solution 1
docs.text:
We try to reflect \(\triangle ABP\) so that \(BP\) is transformed to \(AB\) (sA-type: \(\triangle ABP \sim \triangle QBA\)). Now we try to minimize \(\frac{AQ}{AB}\), but \(AB\) in known, so we minimize \(AQ\).

Notice that \(BP \cdot BQ = AB ^ 2\), this is an inversion. We can derive the locus of \(Q\) based on \(P\), then \(\min(AQ)\) is trivial.

docs.title: Solution 2
docs.text:
We try to rotate \(\triangle ABP\) so that \(BP\) is transformed to \(BO\) (basic rotation: \(\triangle ABP \sim \triangle QBO\)). This also gives us \(\triangle ABQ \sim \triangle PBO\). We try to minimize \(QO\).

We can use inversion again of course (\(BP \cdot BQ = AB \cdot OB\)), but this is slow. Notice that \(\frac{PO}{BO}\) is known. By the similar triangle, we can get \(\frac{AQ}{BQ} = \frac{PO}{BO}\). We can solve this with Apollonius Circle.

docs.title: Note
docs.text: Usually other fixed segments will do as well. And sometimes they can give even simpler answers. An example of this is 2025 T25.3: we can use similar triangles in circle (the external case).

docs.title: Idea 2
docs.text: We try to use Ptolemy's Theorem by construction the inequality with homogenous terms in terms of \(AP\) and \(BP\).

docs.title: Solution 3
docs.text:
The current points \(A ,\, B ,\, O ,\, P\) doesn't given homogenous terms. We need the sides of the quadrilateral to be all in terms of \(AP\) and the diagonals to be in terms of \(BP\).

An easy way to do this will be to treat \(\odot O\) as a Apollonius Circle. By constructing the corresponding point of \(A\) (\(Q\)), we can create another segment (\(PQ\)) in terms of \(AP\). Then the problem can be solved by applying Ptolemy on the quadrilateral \(ABQP\).

docs.title: Bonus Problem
docs.text: Given a isosceles triangle \(\triangle ABC\) with \(\angle BAC = 120\). \(E\) is on \(BC\), \(F\) is on \(AC\), and \(BE = \sqrt{3} CF\). Find \(\max(\frac{AE}{EF})\).

docs.title: Idea
docs.text: Same as Idea 1.

docs.title: Solution 1
docs.text:
We can consider reflecting \(EF\) onto \(AC\) (A-type: \(\triangle AEF \sim \triangle ACD\)). \(EDCF\) are concyclic ⇒ \(\angle ADF = \angle ACB = 30^\circ\). We now want to find the locus of \(D\).

Let DF and EC intersect at \(G\). With \(\angle ADF = 30^\circ\), we can think of two things:

  1. \(ABDG\) are concyclic.
  2. The angle might be formed by a rotation. (Because rotation is common in this knd of \(BD-CF\) setup and the angles match.)

From the concyclic property, we find \(\angle FGC = \angle EGD = \angle AEB\) ⇒ rotation: \(\triangle ABE \sim \triangle GCF\). Thus, \(G\) can be proven to be a fixpoint, and with \(\angle ADG = 30^\circ\), the problem is solved.

docs.title: Solution 2
docs.text:
We rotate \(\triangle AEF \sim \triangle ABG\) and try to find the locus of \(G\) and minimize \(EF\).

From the second pair, we get \(\angle AGF = \angle ABE = \angle ACB\). Let \(AG\) and \(BC\) intersect at \(D\). \(CGDF\) is concyclic. When \(E\) moves from \(B\) to \(C\), we find that \(G\) moves from \(C\) to \(A\). We postulate that \(\angle AGC\) is fixed, but we've already established that \(\angle AGF = 30^\circ\), so we need to find \(\angle FDC\).

We notice that \(\triangle ABE \cong \triangle ACD\) because they're symmetric by reflection. (The congruence here is a special case, in the general version of this problem, we need to construct that concyclic group \(GCDF\) manually and we get a similarity.) Then from the ratio given, we can find \(\angle FDC = 30^\circ\). The problem is trivial from here.

Solution 1 is definitely the go-to method to solve this problem. Solution 2 is just to demonstrate that any path can lead to a solution.

docs.title: Problem
docs.text:
Given two starting points \(A\) and \(B\). Points \(P\) and \(Q\) each start from \(A\), \(B\), and move with velocity vectors \(\mathbf{u}\), \(\mathbf{v}\). \(PB\) and \(QA\) intersects at \(M\). Find the locus of M.

For convenience, let \(AP\) and \(BQ\) intersect at \(C\).

docs.title: Idea
docs.text:
From the velocity vectors, we can see that \(\frac{AP}{BQ} = \frac{\|\mathbf{u}\|}{\|\mathbf{v}\|} = k \,\text{(const.)}\).

If we set the time in motion to be \(+\infty\), \(M\) is at infinity. Therefore, we may guess that \(M\)'s locus is a ray. To pinpoint where this ray is, we have two methods:

  1. Find two fixed points.
  2. Find a fixed intersection and fixed angle in between with another line.

We haven't been given any conditions about angles, so we choose method 2. We can try finding one special point on \(M\)'s locus, extend through \(M\) to intersect another line at a new point, and the problem is solved.

The first two special points we may notice is when \(P\) or \(Q\) is at \(C\). You can solve the problem with these two points (by constructing a line parallel to \(BC\) through \(M\)), but the calculation is messy.

A better special point is when \(t = -\infty\). Here \(BP \parallel AC ,\, AQ \parallel BC\), therefore \(AMBC\) is a parallelogram. This already gives use two parallel lines. To utilize the parallel lines, we can extend \(AQ ,\, BQ\). If we also draw out the first two special points, we find that it forms a dilation structure about \(M\).

docs.title: Solution
docs.text:
Construct the parallelogram \(ASBC\). Extend \(BM\) to intersect \(SA\) at \(D\). Extend \(SM\) to intersect \(BC\) at \(T\).

\(\triangle PAD \sim \triangle PCB\) ⇒ \(AD = \frac{BC \cdot AP}{PC}\) Dilation Ratio: \(r = \frac{MQ}{MA} = \frac{BQ}{AD} = \frac{BQ \cdot PC}{BC \cdot AP}\) \(BT = r \cdot SD = \frac{BQ \cdot PC \cdot SD}{BC \cdot AP} = k \cdot AC\)

docs.title: Problem
docs.text: Given a square \(ABCD\). \(\triangle AMB \cong \triangle BNC\) forms L3A. Connect \(AN\) and \(DM\) to intersect at P. Find the locus of \(P\).

docs.title: Idea
docs.text:
The L3A (part of the inner chordal graph) is a rotation about the square's center \(O\) by \(90^\circ\). \(AN\) is obtained by a clockwise rotation of \(90^\circ\) of \(DM\) about \(O\). Therefore, \(\angle APD = 90\), and the locus is found.

The crucial part, is to prove that it is indeed such a rotation.

docs.title: Solution 1
docs.text:
We first consider how to characterize the rotation of the individual points:

For \(M \rightarrow N\), there are two easy characterizations:

  1. \(AM \rightarrow BN\)
  2. \(BM \rightarrow CN\)

For \(D \rightarrow A\):

  1. \(DO \rightarrow AO\)
  2. You may think that's all, but we can rotate the whole diagonal: \(DB \rightarrow AC\)

We want to choose a pair of characterization that forms a new pair of rotational congruent triangles:

  1. \(BM \rightarrow CN\)
  2. \(DB \rightarrow AC\)

The angle between is easily proven equal, and proving \(\triangle ACN \cong \triangle DMB\) is trivial.

docs.title: Solution 2
docs.text:
We characterize all rotation of \(S\) to \(T\) by \(OS \rightarrow OT\). Then any segment connecting such a pair of points can be easily proven to have same the rotational properties.

We already have \(DO \rightarrow AO\). Now prove \(MO = NO\) and \(\angle MON = 90^\circ\):

Again, we'll have to find two rotational congruent pairs to prove this. One pair will have to be in relationship with \(MN\):

  1. \(AM \rightarrow BN\)
  2. \(BM \rightarrow CN\)

Choosing either can lead to a solution. Take the 2nd for example:

We've now introduced a new rotational pair \(B \rightarrow C\). We can still characterize this pair by connecting to the center.

Now we have:

  1. \(BM \rightarrow CN\)
  2. \(OB \rightarrow OC\)

Then proving \(\triangle OMB \cong \triangle ONC\) and \(\triangle OAN \cong \triangle ODM\) is trivial. You may notice that we can combine these two congruent pairs, and we get the pair in solution 1.

docs.title: Problem
docs.text: Given 2 starting points \(A\) and \(B\), \(P\) and \(Q\) are each moving with velocity \(\mathbf{u}\) and \(\mathbf{v}\). Find the minimum of $PQ.

docs.title: Idea 1
docs.text: \(P\) and \(Q\) are in relative motion. We can move to \(P\)'s reference frame. This is two points in motion.

docs.title: Solution 1
docs.text: We add \(\vec{PA}\) to everything to get \(P\) stationary (construct parallelogram \(APQR\), where \(R\) is the transformed \(Q\)). In \(\triangle BQR\), we find that \(R\) starts from \(B\) and moves with velocity \(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{u}\). The locus of \(R\) is found and \(\min(PQ) = \min(AR)\) is trivial.

docs.title: Idea 2
docs.text: We can treat \(\vec{BQ}\) to be rotated from \(\vec{AP}\). (Note: We match the fixed with the fixed.)

docs.title: Solution 2
docs.text:
Let the angle between \(\mathbf{u}\) and \(\mathbf{v}\) be \(\theta\). The rotational center \(O\) can be found with \(\angle AOB = \theta\) and \(\frac{AO}{BO} = \frac{\|\mathbf{u}\|}{\|\mathbf{v}\|} = k\). (Note: The method mentioned in basic rotation is only used to find the position. The properties about the position can only be found with some other method after the center is constructed.)

By the second pair \(\triangle POQ \sim \triangle AOB\), we find that the shape of \(\triangle POQ\) is fixed.

Specifically:

\[PO = \frac{k}{\sqrt{k^2 - 2 \cos(\theta) k + 1}} PQ\] \[QO = \frac{1}{\sqrt{k^2 - 2 \cos(\theta) k + 1}} PQ\]

Using either will give us a method to transform \(PQ\) into something trivial. This method also has an advantage over the first, because the transformed segment have one end as the original endpoint.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
I've thought about the naming of this section, ended up with "Line Construction". As the name says, this section basically covers how we can construct to relate figures primarily made up of lines. These are also the main constructions we can use in similar triangles (other than rotation which is universal.)

This is essentially a replacement for 1st order equations in analytic geometry. (By "replacement", I MEAN replacement. Anything you can do with 1st order equations, you can do with methods in this section.)

There are two kinds of structures: Parallel Lines & Intersecting Lines

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
This is one of the two main parts of similar triangles (the other is Parallel Lines.)

The structures here are basically the structures in parallel lines + reflection. This also contains connections to circles. Products (instead of ratios) are more commonly used. In fact, all ratios can be written as products, but their order is usually reversed, making them mostly useless. However, here the reflection flips the order, and makes the product easier to think about than ratios.

This type of structure can also be thought of as a non-linear transformation.

Though the section is called Intersecting Lines, most kinds of intersection problems actually uses Parallel Lines. The "intersect" actually means that the corresponding side of the similar triangles intersect.

docs.title: Basic Structure
docs.text:
\[ \triangle OAB \sim \triangle OCD \]

There are actually 2 sub-cases:

  1. \(AB\) and \(CD\) are on the same side. (A-type)
  2. \(AB\) and \(CD\) are on opposite sides of \(O\). (X-type)

docs.title: Properties
docs.text:
1. $ OA \cdot OD = OB \cdot OC $
  2. \(ABCD\) are concyclic ⇒ other similar triangles
  3. $ \frac{AB}{CD} = \frac{OA}{OC} = \frac{OB}{OD} $

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
1. Collinear products
  2. Concyclic quadrilaterals
  3. When auxiliary parallel lines doesn't give results, try its reflection.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
1. 《核心考点·中考数学》P24 06 (this is an excellent example of inscribed triangle in a rectangle)
  2. P22 05

docs.title: Extra Special Case
docs.text:
This is the sA-type but with \(\angle OAC = \angle OBA = 90^\circ\).

This condition creates another coincident rotation and sA-type as shown bellow.

docs.title: Properties
docs.text:
1. \(\triangle OAB \sim \triangle OCA \sim \triangle ACB\)
  2. \(OA ^ 2 = OB \cdot OC\) and \(AC ^ 2 = BC \cdot OC\) (from sA-type)
  3. \(AB ^ 2 = OB \cdot CB\) (from coincident rotation)
  4. \(\frac{OB}{CB} = \frac{AO^2}{AC^2}\) (derived from 2nd)

Here are the results in use: Let \(AO = a\), \(AC = b\), \(OC = \sqrt{a^2 + b^2}\).

  1. \(AB = \frac{AO \cdot AC}{OC} = \frac{ab}{\sqrt{a^2 + b^2}}\) (IMPORTANT)
  2. \(OB = \frac{AO ^ 2}{OC} = \frac{a^2}{\sqrt{a^2 + b^2}}\)
  3. \(CB = \frac{AC ^ 2}{OC} = \frac{b^2}{\sqrt{a^2 + b^2}}\)

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
1. When a lot of right angles are around (like in L3A with \(90^\circ\)).
  2. As this is a sA-type case, it does generate a Apollonius Circle, and \(AC\) is tangent to \(\odot O\).

docs.title: Special Case (sA-type)
docs.text: This is the A-type, but \(A\) and \(D\) are the same.

docs.title: Basic Usage
docs.text:
Just use the properties like normal.

The only special thing is that this gives squares instead of just products.

\[ OA ^ 2 = OB \cdot OD \]

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
1. 《核心考点·中考数学》P21 03 04
  2. 《核心考点·中考数学》P41 (HARD)

docs.title: Apollonius Circle
docs.text: Discussed in Circles.

docs.title: Definition
docs.text:
Given a point \(P\), the center of inversion \(O\), and the radius of inversion \(r\).

The inverted point \(P'\) is on ray \(\overset{\Large\rightarrow}{OP}\), and \(OP \cdot OP' = r^2\).

docs.title: Properties and Derivation
docs.text:
The inversion of a circle is another circle. Here lines are considered circles of \(r = \infty\).

Derivation:

  1. Construct the diameter (\(MN\)) of \(\odot A\) that goes through \(O\) ⇒ \(\angle MPN = 90^\circ\)
  2. Construct the inversion (\(M'N'\)) of \(MN\) ⇒ \(\triangle OPM \sim \triangle OM'P' ,\, \triangle OPN \sim \triangle ON'P'\)
  3. \(\angle M'P'N' = 90^\circ\) ⇒ \(P'\) is on a circle with diameter \(M'N'\)

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
1. Used to solve ratio extremum (R_n)
  2. Find locus (usually the \(OP \cdot OP' = r^2\) is derived)

docs.title: Transformation 3
docs.text: I've found no other mention of this type anywhere, thus the crude name.

docs.title: Construction
docs.text:
1. \(P\) is on line \(l\), \(A ,\, B\) are fixed endpoints.
  2. \(\triangle PAB \sim \triangle PBQ\), where \(Q\) is on \(AP\)

docs.title: Derivation
docs.text:
1. Construct the reflection of \(B\) (\(B'\)) about \(l\).
  2. \(B'P^2 = BP^2 = PQ \cdot PA\), hence \(\triangle PAB' \sim \triangle PB'Q\).
  3. \(\frac{B'Q}{B'A} = \frac{B'P}{AP} = \frac{BP}{AP} = \frac{BQ}{BA}\).
  4. \(\frac{BQ}{B'Q} = \frac{BA}{B'A} = \text{const.}\) ⇒ Apollonius Circle

docs.title: Explanation
docs.text:
Currently, I'm unable to think of an explanation not containing some guesswork.

The main thing to notice here is that \(A\) is on \(Q\)'s locus (when \(AP = BP\)). We can immediately see that the locus isn't a line (so it's a circle).

Since there is NO fixed angles here, if we want to go forward with this method, we need to construct our own. Try with \(BH \perp l\), this will characterize l with the distance from \(B\) to \(l\), and give use a fixed angle. However, this construction doesn't work because unlike in inversion, the relationship given here cannot give us another triangle (containing \(Q\) as the \(90^\circ\) vertex) similar to \(\triangle BHP\).

Try with Apollonius Circle. There are only two fixed points \(A\) and \(B\), \(A\) is on the locus, therefore we can guess that \(B\) is one of the endpoints. That gives us some fixpoint \(B'\) s.t. \(\frac{BQ}{B'Q} = \frac{BA}{B'A}\). When we rearrange the equation, we can see the similarity ratio of \(\triangle PAB \sim \triangle PBQ\), so we can construct the same for \(B'\). That actually allows use to backtrack to \(B'P = BP\), and since \(B'\) needs to be fixed, \(B\) and \(B'\) are mirrored about \(l\).

With this thought process, we can also see why \(P\) has to be on a line. When \(P\) is on a circle, we can still construct \(B'\) with Apollonius Circle. But \(B'P \neq BP\), going against "backtrack to \(B'P = BP\)", therefore the locus is some much more complex 4th order thing.

docs.title: Further Reading
docs.text: Another non-linear transformation is Rolling Similarity.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text: This is one of the two main parts of similar triangles (the other is Intersecting Lines.)

docs.title: Basic Idea
docs.text: This is a way to scale (dilate) a sub-figure to some size (or orientation, when factor \(k < 0\)), so that we can obtain its relationship to other structures at this same scale.

docs.title: Construction Criteria
docs.text:
1. DO NOT split current / to be solved ratios, unless there is no other path forward. (Otherwise you'll end up with a mess of equations if you can solve it at all.)
  2. Any construction (path) made here must link at least 2 parameters. Think of this as a graph search: for any path from start to end, there is 1 LESS edge than vertex.

docs.title: Basic Structure
docs.text: This is the MOST basic structures in this Line Construction. Everything else stems from here.

docs.title: Properties
docs.text:
1. \(\frac{AC}{DC} = \frac{BC}{EC} = \frac{AB}{DE}\)
  2. \(DE \parallel AB\)
  3. \(\frac{CD}{AD} = \frac{CE}{BE}\) (this is derived from the first)

Any single property (except SSA case) can be used to derive the other properties

docs.title: Use Case
docs.text:
• Used when the segments in the ratio are COLLINEAR ⇒ construct parallel lines with one end being the ratio.
  • Used when the segments in the ratio are PARALLEL ⇒ extend the end vertices to intersect.
  • Used when the segments in the ratio have a common vertex ⇒ construct parallel line of the segment of non-common vertex.

This basically covers everything, which is expected, as this can substitute analytic geometry.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
1. R_n (hidden special point on the locus that generates parallel lines)
  2. 《核心考点·中考数学》P24 06 (also requires A-type)

docs.title: Dilation
docs.text: You might find that simply using the Basic Structure doesn't yield any results (this happens whenever you can't find another segment that intersects the current and can link to another itself). Then try moving both of them out together, namely, using dilation, to a scale where other conditions can be put into use.

docs.title: Properties
docs.text: \[ \frac{AB}{BC} = \frac{A'B'}{B'C'} \]

docs.title: Use Case
docs.text:
Used when two segments share a vertex, and a line goes through one of the three vertices (preferably the shared one).

Also, this method doesn't require the segments to be collinear (though most of the time they are.)

docs.title: Examples
docs.text: 1. 《核心考点·中考数学》P18 03

docs.title: Midline
docs.text: Though this section is called midline, the results doesn't only apply to the midpoints. It's only that midpoint are the most common.

docs.title: Construction
docs.text: Given a trapezoid \(ABCD\) (\(AB \parallel CD\)). \(E ,\, F\) are on \(AD ,\, BC\), \(\frac{AE}{AD} = \frac{BF}{BC} = k\).

docs.title: Properties
docs.text:
1. \(EF \parallel AB \parallel CD\)
  2. \(EF = k CD + (1 - k) AB\)

docs.title: Use Case
docs.text:
1. There are many collinear segments with ratio \(k\) ⇒ construct the same ratio and connect midpoints.
  2. \(k = \frac{1}{2}\) + add / subtrack segments ⇒ midline of trapezoid.
  3. \(kCD\) ⇒ "midline" with ratio \(k\)

docs.title: Basic Rotation
docs.text: Essentially this is \(\triangle OAB \sim \triangle OCD\). Or you can understand this at segment rotation.

docs.title: Properties
docs.text:
1. \(\triangle OAB \sim \triangle OCD \Leftrightarrow \triangle OAC \sim \triangle OBD\)
  2. Concyclic Groups (from Angle Rotation):
    • \(ACIO\)
    • \(BDIO\)
    • \(ABJO\)
    • \(CDJO\)

docs.title: Note
docs.text:
When \((O,B,C)\) or \((O,A,B)\) are collinear, then (using \((O,B,C)\) as example): 1. \(OB \cdot OC = OA \cdot OD\) 2. \(OA(OB)\) bisects \(\angle AOD\)

This can be used to transform products when the segments are collinear.

These properties reduce when \((B,C)\) or \((A,D)\) are the same. Specifically:

  1. the 1st property reduces completely.
  2. the 2nd property:
    • \(CD\) is tangent to \(\odot OAB\)
    • \(AB\) is tangent to \(\odot OCD\)
  3. the product turns into a square

For the concyclic properties, see Angle Rotation for more information.

docs.title: Finding Rotational Center
docs.text:
Let segments be \(AB ,\, A'B'\)

  1. Find the segments' intersection \(S\)
  2. Construct \(\odot ASA' ,\, \odot BSB'\)
  3. The circle's intersection (other that \(S\)) is the rotational center

This is AA construction + derive from concyclic points.

docs.title: Note
docs.text: If S is the same as \(A / B / C / D\), then construct tangent circles (in property notes.)

docs.title: Construction
docs.text:
1. AA
  2. SAS (with O as vertex)

docs.title: Derivation
docs.text:
1. SAS with \(A\), \(B\), \(C\), or \(D\) as vertex
  2. Derive back from concyclic property (construction 1)
  3. From the other pair in property 1 (construction 2)

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
1. To add / subtract segments:
    • 《核心考点·中考数学》P34 06
    • Ptolemy's Theorem
  2. (P)oint in Triangle:
    • Idea: connect \(PA ,\, PB ,\, PC\), then rotate appropriate triangle out (e.g. \(\triangle ABP \rightarrow \triangle BCP'\))
    • P34 07 08
    • Fermat's Point
    • P42
  3. derivation 1: P34 05
  4. derivation 2: P34 06
  5. derivation 3: R4

docs.title: General Rotation
docs.text:
In Basic Rotation, we've covered the rotation of segments. Here we'll talk about the rotation of triangles.

This is an idea, rather than actual construction. So some of the construction is actually redundant and is only useful for thinking.

docs.title: Construction
docs.text:
1. Construct the rotational center for one edge.
  2. Connect vertices to the rotational center, and use Basic Rotation.

docs.title: Basic Idea
docs.text: Sometimes the connection to rotational center is unnecessary. However, we usually do need to know that the figure in question DOES contain such a rotation. Usually, either only constructing the rotated triangle or using the center of rotation will yield a solution. But in special circumstances, the only way forward is with the rotational center. In these case, we can try to combine sides from different rotational pairs to construct a new rotational pair.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
1. L3A (which has its own set of ideas)
  2. R1
  3. R6 (天河期末, to be included)

docs.title: Construction
docs.text:
Given an angle (\(\angle AMB\)) in an odd orientation.

Obviously we can use a rotation, but sometimes that doesn't connect to the conditions given directly. Then we might be required to translate the rotated result to another position (essentially constructing a parallelogram.)

This is basically L3A.

  1. Construct a line in the "normal" direction going through \(A\).
  2. Find two point on the line satisfying \(\angle ACM = \angle AMB = \angle MDB\).
  3. \(\triangle ACM \sim \triangle MDB\) (\(AC \cdot MC = BC \cdot MD\))

docs.title: Middle Intersection
docs.text:
Instead of an angle with rays, we're given two lines with a rotational angle. The most common structure is the lines inscribed in a parallelogram.

We can translate again, but that is slow. We can actually construct the original similarity (but translated) directly. That may speed things up a lot.

docs.title: Midpoint L3A
docs.text:
When \(M\) is the midpoint of \(CD\), then this becomes a rolling similarity. (i.e. \(\triangle ACM \sim \triangle AMB \sim \triangle MDB\), \(A\) and \(B\) are the rotational centers.)

This case only occurs when \(CD\) doesn't pass through the interior of \(\angle AMB\). When it does, then this reduces to coincident rotation.

docs.title: Special Property
docs.text:
Extend \(AC\) and \(BD\) to intersect at \(E\).

\(AM\) and \(BM\) bisects \(\angle CAB\) and \(\angle DBA\) ⇒ \(M\) is the incenter of \(\triangle ABE\).

docs.title: Parallel Sides
docs.text:
Instead of \(\angle ACM = \angle MDB\), we have \(\angle MAC = \angle AMB = \angle MDB\) ⇒ \(AC \parallel MB\).

Used to transform ratios.

(Only usage I've seen is in 《核心考点·中考数学》P17 02)

docs.title: Rotation and Chordal Graph
docs.text:
The L3A similarity can also be seen as a rotation itself.

In a regular polygon, the triangle can be rotated multiple times to give the chordal graph.

It also gives a new type of L3A with one end constrained to one of the vertices of the polygon, and another end walking on an adjacent side.

Usually the rotation is just a tool for thinking, rather than an actual step in problem-solving. In the cases (e.g. 某年天河期末 R6) where the rotation is actually a crucial step, we can usually combine the corresponding sides in different types of chordal graph to construct a new rotational pair.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
1. Transform angles (or triangles) in an odd orientation.
  2. Find intersections of a circle and line (《核心考点·中考数学》P30 03). This is a special application of the first use case.

docs.title: Rolling Similarity
docs.text: Note: This is more like and example problem rather than a typical structure.

docs.title: Problem
docs.text: Given a fixed segment \(AB\), a fixed point \(C\), and a point \(P\) moving along a line (or circle, just ensure that after an inversion transformation, its path is still simple). Rotate \(\triangle ABP\) to \(\triangle CQP\) (i.e \(\triangle ABP \sim \triangle CQP\).) Find the locus of \(Q\).

docs.title: A Reduced Problem
docs.text:
Let first look at the case where \(C\) and \(B\) are the same. We'll try to find some fixed point with some product relationship with \(P\) and \(Q\).

This is a rotational similarity with collinear side. After enumerating the properties of this similarity, we find that there is obviously no fixpoint besides \(A\) and \(B\). The products concerning \(A\) and \(B\) aren't useful, so we can try to construct.

Let the similarity ratio be \(k\). We find that everything besides \(AB\) and \(AP\) have a coefficient of \(k^n\), therefore we need to reduce the order of \(k\). We can notice that \(PQ\) is one order higher than \(BQ\), so we can try dividing \(BQ\) by their ratio again to cancel the \(k\). That gives \(\triangle QPB \sim \triangle QBD\), \(BD = AB\), and \(QD = \frac{AB^2}{AP}\). If we choose \(D\) to give another roational similarity, then we find that D is also a fixpoint.

With fixpoint D and \(QD = \frac{AB^2}{AP}\), we can solve the problem with inversion.

(You may also recognize the structure as midpoint L3A.)

docs.title: Original Problem Solution
docs.text:
Based on the reduced version, we can try constructing \(\triangle ABP \sim \triangle CQP \sim \triangle DQB\). (This is where this structure gets its name: we first rotate about \(P\) then about \(Q\).) This gives \(QD \cdot AP = AB \cdot BD\). We can postulate that D is a fixpoint, then the problem is solved.

To prove this, we notice that when we constructed the similar triangle, we also constructed \(\triangle PBQ\), which is one of the rotation's second set of similar triangles. We can connect \(CD\), and we can find \(CD = AB\) via \(\triangle PQB \sim \triangle CQD\) and \(\triangle ABP \sim \triangle CQP\). Extend \(DC\) to intersect \(PB\) at \(E\), from rotation, we find that \(PQCE\) are concyclic. \(\angle BED = \angle PQC = \angle PBA\) ⇒ \(CD \parallel AB\). (Extending \(AB\) to intersect QC also works.) Therefore, \(D\) is fixed.

We can also think about constructing the fixpoint D first with the second similarity, then work back to the original rotation.

docs.title: L3A
docs.text:
When \(ABC\) are collinear, then the first and last triangle in the rolling sequence forms a L3A. When \(C\) and \(B\) are the same, it's a midpoint L3A.

However, most of the time, it's a kind of pseudo-L3A where the equal angles do not fall on a single line. The product relationship still holds up (that's what makes the inversion possible).

This also tells how to construct the intermediate triangle from the first and last:

  1. Find the circumcircle \(\odot O\) of \(\triangle PQB\)
  2. \(\odot O\) intersects \(AB\) at \(E\)
  3. Find \(C\) on \(QE\) s.t. \(CD \parallel AB\)
  4. \(\triangle PQC\) is the intermediate triangle.

docs.title: Intersecting Lines' Special Case
docs.text: There, we've discussed three non-linear transformations. This is the next in the series.

docs.title: Key Takeaways
docs.text:
1. Analyze relationships between different segments, and construct to make the relationships "simple". (Like how the construction here generates parallelogram \(ABDC\).) Order of expression is usually useful.
  2. Try simpler versions of the problem (special cases) to get of feeling of the problem.

docs.title: How to Derive Transformation Matrices
docs.text:
1. Start out with the basis vectors \(\hat{\mathbf{x}} ,\, \hat{\mathbf{y}}\)
  2. Find their transformed results: \(\hat{\mathbf{x}} \rightarrow \mathbf{u} ,\, \hat{\mathbf{y}} \rightarrow \mathbf{v}\)
  3. Put them together:
\[ \begin{bmatrix} -\mathbf{u}- \\ -\mathbf{v}- \end{bmatrix} \]

docs.title: Euler's Formula
docs.text:
\[ e^{ix} = \cos(x) + i \sin(x) \]

Let \(u = e^{ix}\), then:

\[ \begin{align*} & \sin(x) = \frac{u - \frac{1}{u}}{2i} \\ & \cos(x) = \frac{u + \frac{1}{u}}{2} \end{align*} \]

Useful for subsitution.

Though sometimes we can use:

\[ \sin(x) = \frac{a - b}{2} ,\, cos(x) = \frac{a + b}{2} \\ \Rightarrow a^2 + b^2 = 2 \]

docs.title: Angle summation
docs.text:
This directly follows from Euler's formula:

\[ \begin{align*} &\sin(x + y) = \sin(x)\cos(y) + \cos(x)\sin(y) \\ &\cos(x + y) = \cos(x)\cos(y) - \sin(x)\sin(y) = 2 \cos^2(x) - 1 \\ &\tan(x + y) = \frac{\tan(x) + \tan(y)}{1 - \tan(x)\tan(y)} \end{align*} \]

docs.title: Sine Formula
docs.text:
\[ \frac{a}{\sin(A)} = \frac{b}{\sin(b)} = \frac{c}{\sin(c)} = d \]

where d is the diameter of the circumcircle. Used in AAS / ASA / circum-radius calculation. (The derivation of its relationship to d is in Orthocenter.)

Also used for area calculation (or transform triangle area with known angle):

\[ S_{\triangle ABC} = \frac{1}{2} a b \sin(C) = \frac{1}{2} \mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b} \]

(Examples: R4)

docs.title: Cosine Formula
docs.text:
\[ c^2 = a^2 + b^2 - 2ab \cos(C) \]

Used in SSA. Vector dot product's derivation also follows from here.
